text:
Did you know a rainbow coloured film or thick sludge on the beach or in the sea can indicate oil #pollution? üåà

If you spot oil, please report it to @EnvAgency & the  council, who will investigate & clean it up to protect wildlife ‚òéÔ∏èüêü 

More info - https://t.co/jU6ZkFAPua https://t.co/FkTaDae7fN

text:
Having a 'trigger' to notify you of a #flood BEFORE it happens can allow time to prepare.

The @EnvAgencyNW Flood Warning Service is one such trigger, but do you know what the different stages mean?

Read our blog to learn more: https://t.co/5Hv1sf3FoV

#preparedness #floodaware https://t.co/7SEKTJFMnd

urls.title: Flood Alert, Flood Warning and Severe Flood Warning ‚Äì What‚Äôs the difference? | Newground
urls.description: Recently, I saw a poll on Twitter set up to help the Environment Agency understand people‚Äôs interpretation of flood risk, which is one of the reasons I decided to write this blog. Out of the 1,199 people who voted on the poll, I was quite shocked to find that 51% of voters thought a Flood Alert meant that you were at a higher risk of flooding than a Flood Warning. This is NOT the case. Raising awareness of the flood alerts and warning system and what each stage means is key to educating people and

text:
In 2020, 14% of UK rivers reached a good ecological standard and 100% of them failed to reach a good chemical standard. The report from @EnvAgency highlights clear room for improvement as more accurate testing is introduced. 

More: https://t.co/Vc5mQnNF4y

#marineconservation

urls.title: Shocking state of English rivers revealed as all of them fail pollution tests
urls.description: Data reveals just 14% of good ecological standard and none of good chemical standard

domain.name: TV Shows
domain.description: Television shows from around the world

entity.name: Countryfile
entity.description: Stories are shared of the people, places and issues at the heart of the British countryside. Popular features include the programme's photography contest, which culminates in a yearly calendar sold to benefit charity, the Video Diary, produced by viewers and focused on life in rural areas, and the weather forecasts.

domain.name: TV Shows
domain.description: Television shows from around the world

entity.name: Springwatch
entity.description: Following the fortunes of a cast of unforgettable wildlife characters at the climax of spring.

domain.name: TV Shows
domain.description: Television shows from around the world

entity.name: Countryfile Diaries
entity.description: A sister show to the BBC's `Countryfile' series, this rural affairs programme sees a team of presenters travel the length and breadth of the United Kingdom to cover stories related to the British countryside and the season of spring. As this period is a busy time of the year for the farming and outdoor communities in particular, regular topics covered include the production of food, nature conservation, and a look at a chosen area's culture and history. Stunning landscapes and a variety of wildlife also feature prominently.

urls.title: Have Your Say! | The Flood Hub
urls.description: Please share your feedback with us about this exhibition. Your responses will help inform future planning by the Environment Agency. Your participation is optional, and you can stop answering at any point before you press submit. We are not collecting any identifying data so all responses will be anonymous. The information we collect here may be used in academic publications and the results will be disseminated on The Flood Hub website (www.thefloodhub.co.uk). For more infor mation about how to prepare
